sense.name: the general populace, people in general
sense.examples: These museum are all open to the public free of charge. The debates are intended to allow the public to make an informed choice when they vote. The public's support of this issue has gradually eroded over the past twelve months.

sense.name: people sharing a common interest or pursuit
sense.commentary: PUBLIC[+people][+community][+interest][+shared] Note: always implies a shared interest, pursuit or goal among the group Note: usually preceded by a modifier that denotes the interest or goal.
sense.examples: The new French-Cuban bistro has gotten rave reviews from the dining public of this city. The film star has been avoiding his public since the sex scandal. (his fans) The closing of another newspaper does a disservice to our reading public.

sense.name: a place that is generally accessible to all, not private
sense.examples: The child sat down on the sidewalk and threw a temper tantrum in public. Sally is terrified to speak in public.

sense.name: an official who authenticates documents, signatures
sense.examples: You will need to have these forms signed by a notary public. His deposition was taken down by a notary public.
